text: Preventing users from posting infringing materials obviously requires a filter. Proponents of A13 say other methods are possible, but no other method has been identified, because no other method exists.
author: doctorow

text: If I demand that you produce a large, four-legged, African land mammal with a trunk, tusk and a tail, you are going to give me an elephant, even if I say, "But try not to make it an elephant."
author: doctorow

text: The core of A13 is that it creates liability for users' copyright infringement BEFORE the platform is notified and removes it. Though A13 doesn't say "use filters to solve this," there is no way to assess copyright in billions of posts without a filter.
author: doctorow

text: The problems caused by filters will fall more to individuals and independent artists than those who have signed away rights to big companies that have licensing departments that can get the platforms' senior staff on the phone.
author: doctorow

text: Saying "they're not required" is not the same as them not being required. Please go read the directive and the legislative analysis of it. Giant corporations have back-channels into each other (when Macmillan requests takedowns from Amazon they get more action than when I do it)

text: That means that filters will generate literally millions of copyright disputes EVERY DAY. Even if they staff the appeals function with high-paid, thoughtful, trained people, you're looking at weeks or months to process appeals.
author: doctorow

text: Here's the basic maths: FB gets billions of posts. Less than 1% represent infringements. Filters have >1% false positive rates (these grow with the number and type of works they're filtering for).
author: doctorow

text: Given how much potential copyrighted material flows through FB, it's inconceivable that they'd have enough people to expeditiously process all the claims an A13 filter would generate.
author: doctorow

text: Books on Amazon are a VERY narrow category and Amazon has a VERY high ratio of customer service reps:content by industry standards. FB has millions of times more works (posts, pics, videos) and a fraction of the CSRs.
author: doctorow

text: The system would automatically match the earlier claim. We could go through Amazon's adjudication system, but speaking as someone who uses that system on a weekly basis, it takes MONTHS. So my book would only be avail through a counterfeiter through the initial release window
author: doctorow

text: Sure. I have to counterfeits of my novels removed from Amazon all the time. It's tedious and slow. Under A13, if a rando took a book on its publication date in US/Canada and uploaded it to Amazon UK before my UK publisher, they wouldn't be able to post it.
author: doctorow

text: "So you must accept all A13 claims & start enforcing them instantaneously and then adjudicate disputes after the fact. Even making us show you the articles of incorporation of a new special purpose LLC formed to produce a film is too much, so you can't verify identities either."
author: doctorow

text: Here's what the rightsholders said when we asked to have copyright claims validated before they were filtered under A13: "If a movie leaks a week before release date, we can't afford to wait a week for you to process our claim amid the millions of others you'll be receiving."
author: doctorow

author: doctorow

text: But all these deficiencies in the DMCA are worsened, not fixed, in A13. This is notice-and-staydown in action: YT accepts copyright claims at face value, then automatically enforces them. The enforcement is instant and automatic, the appeals process is slow and unreliable.
author: doctorow

text: If I claim your works, you can sue me (assuming you can figure out who I am, because, again, A13 doesn't require platforms to verify my identity, much less my claims). Or you can sue the platform. Or try your luck with whatever mediation system the platform has.
author: doctorow

text: I don't have to show any evidence of authorship to claim a work under A13. That's the problem! Or at least one of them. We asked to have that put into A13, and the rightsholder orgs said it was too much of a burden, and blocked it.
author: doctorow

text: No, Trevor, honestly, that would be a much more sensible system -- not one I favour, but much better than the one currently proposed. However, that proposal WAS REJECTED during A13 drafting. That's NOT what we're getitng.
author: doctorow

text: You could use fake identities to upload all of Shakespeare or Rhodin or Brahms 30 times/day, faster than the platforms could remove them, for example. This would cost pennies.
author: doctorow

text: All of these were rejected. Instead, under A13, platforms (over EUR5M/year, or 3 years old) are liable if users post copyrighted material, and cannot ignore copyright claims from known bad actors
author: doctorow

text: Maintain public statistics on A13 claims so that we can tell whether it's working, whether it's being abused, and who is abusing it.
author: doctorow

text: Disqualify rightsholders from accessing the streamlined A13 process if they repeatedly fail to exercise care, and instead require that they use the traditional system of showing evidence and getting a court order
author: doctorow

text: Repeatedly during the A13 negotiations, we asked for checks and balances in the copyright claims process: make rightsholders affirmatively identify themselves with multiple checks to block impersonation/identity theft
author: doctorow

text: And on the other hand you have out-and-out grifters who simply claim other peoples' copyright, take their money and then disappear:
author: doctorow

text: Or the newscasters (5 of them!) who uploaded footage taken from NASA's Mars lander livestream before NASA did, and then blocked NASA from uploading it:
author: doctorow

text: This isn't a hypothetical, either. On the one hand, you have sloppy, giant rightsholders who upload other peoples' works and claim them, like Sony did for this stock media creator (Sony refused to admit error and called HIM a pirate for uploading his work)
author: doctorow

text: So if *I* upload your works before you do, I can keep you from posting your works (or taking them down). What's more, even if I'm a repeat offender, platforms are not allowed to terminate my access to the staydown system under A13.
author: doctorow

text: But even the Notice-and-Staydown provisions in #A13 are deficient, because the drafters rejected all proposals to require platforms to validate copyright claims before adding them to a staydown filter.

text: You're right, this is an impossible burden, because, as you say, FB can't know about all the copyrights in the world, including the ones that were created mere moments ago. That is an objection that opponents to #A13 have persistently raised through the entire process.
author: doctorow

text: #A13 removes that system and replaces it with one where you are obliged to license the copyrights your user might use and block any copyrighted works you haven't licensed.
author: doctorow

text: Under #A13, Facebook is charged with ensuring that copyrights are not infringed, full stop. If you're OK with a system of notice-and-takedown, you should be happy, because that is the system under the 2001 EUCD (and the 1998 US DMCA).
author: doctorow

text: No, you have failed to understand what #A13 represents. You are describing how things work under Safe Harbour: if Facebook expeditiously removes infringing work upon notice, they have no liability. #A13 ends that.

text: This is at the relatively minor scale of Youtube. Now imagine ContentID was policing every word, image and video that you, me, or anyone else sent on Twitter or Facebook -- the idea that this orders-of-magnitude scaling up would make these kangaroo courts better is not credible.
author: doctorow

text: A quick search for "copyfraud" and "content id" will turn up an endless parade of horrors from people who've had their funds misappropriated and their work censored with absolute impunity.
author: doctorow

text: But large corporate rightsholders have backchannels into the Big Tech platforms that give them speedy service -- for example, when counterfeit editions of my novels show up on Amazon, my emails do nothing, but a letter from Macmillan gets swift results.
author: doctorow

text: In every case I've encountered in 10+ years of tracking this, everyday people find it virtually impossible to get a hearing and any kind of reasonable adjudication out of Google unless someone like me publicizes it and embarrasses the company
author: doctorow

text: Here's AIDS deniers using fraudulent claims to remove criticism of their pseudoscience:
author: doctorow

text: I'm not a fraudster, so no. But others have, including large corporate rigthsholders. Here's Lionsgate using fraudulent claims to remove critical reviews of its movies:
author: doctorow

text: Mediterranean Case Study / Enric Ruiz-Geli http://rollership.tumblr.com/post/183182773176/architorturedsouls-mediterranean-case-study … /2
author: doctorow

text: The proportion is irrelevant: the magnitude is what's important. If a modest system allows thousand of fraudsters to exploit a few million rightsholders, then scaling that up would create millions of fraudsters exploiting tens of millions of rightsholders.
author: doctorow

text: Of course. But when I upload your work and claim it as mine, and you come along 10 minutes later and dispute that claim, a filter needs to be able to adjudicate the claim. Otherwise it's just a land-rush: whomever claims the most works gets to permanently own them.
author: doctorow

text: This one from last month, for example (just the most recent, these have been a recurring theme for years)
author: doctorow

text: FIAT Spider, 1961 http://danismm.tumblr.com/post/183182102744/fiat-spider-1961 …
author: doctorow

text: No. That's the point: despite only allowing a tiny subset of "vetted rightsholders" into the system, ContentID is *full* of false claims, because vetting is hard, and because ContentID won't (for example) remove UMG despite multiple false claims.
author: doctorow

text: So #Article13 stands to magnify, not mitigate, every problem with ContentID and similar systems, on unimaginable scale, for every form of communication, from dating sites to education systems to health systems.
author: doctorow

text: Tellingly, all requests to include language in Article 13 that would punish rightsholders who made false copyright claims to misappropriate funds or censor others' work were rejected.
author: doctorow

text: It covers all media types: photos, audio, video, text (including things like software code pasted into message boards for technical analysis)
author: doctorow

text: A13 requires that no copyrighted work of any sort (including this tweet, which attracts a copyright at the moment that I type it) be made public without permission, even for an instant. It accepts claims from every copyright holder (that is, all 2 billion internet users).
author: doctorow

text: Moreover, ContentID does a *tiny* fraction of what #Article13 contemplates: it only allows vetted rightsholders to make claims, it only looks at videos.
author: doctorow

text: It is notoriously high-handed, slow and unresponsive to requests for adjudication and appeal, with claimants caught in endless machine-generated email loops.
author: doctorow

text: It is, nevertheless, easy for "bad guys" to defeat: because infringers can test the limits of ContentID's fuzzy matching for free (creating throwaway accounts and uploading works to find the limits), ContentD also allows mountains of infringing material through
author: doctorow

text: It is strewn with false positives, in which works of original creativity are falsely identified as belonging to someone other than their authors.
author: doctorow

text: ContentID and all of its competitors fail on every one of these metrics. It is riven with high-profile examples of copyfraud, where works are falsely claimed in order to misappropriate money owned to their creators.
author: doctorow

text: 4. Must have a speedy, transparent and fair system of appeals.
author: doctorow

text: 3. However, it must also be able to determine when a claimed  work appears but is not an infringement (e.g. if I am a news photog  whose image of police brutality at a demonstration includes a bus-ad with some stock it, the  system should not block my picture)
author: doctorow

text: 2. Be able to identify claimed works in user uploads, even when transformed
author: doctorow

text:
For an automated system to work it must:

1. Be able to verify copyright claims (that is, if I upload your work and claim it as mine, it has to be able to adjudicate our conflicting claims of ownership)
author: doctorow

text: Druid https://wilwheaton.tumblr.com/post/183181176457 …
author: doctorow

text: The issue isn't the claim, it's that the automated system can't distinguish between works claimed by rightsholders and different works created by different rightsholders.
author: doctorow

text:
"Many at #bigtech  have for years gone to great lengths to show content owners that their  ability to recognise content and thereby monetise it was highly  effective"

That's marketing copy, not evidence.
author: doctorow

text: This is a system that attributes copyrighted status to *silence*.
author: doctorow

text: There is a common pathology wherein people observe that Big Tech are compulsive liars about every aspect of their business (they are!) except for the most extreme claims in their sales literature, which are treated as absolutely trustworthy.
